Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Molecular and Biochemical Analysis of Proteins
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana, will provide research training for eight students for ten weeks during the summers of 2015- 2017. The program provides advanced training in the manipulation and analysis of proteins. The program provides students with a better understanding of laboratory research, insights into protein biochemistry, and an appreciation for the broader context of research. Students work on projects under the guidance of faculty in the Department of Biochemistry. Students can select from a variety of projects including the elucidation of enzyme mechanisms, post-translational protein modifications, proteomics, protein-nucleic acid interactions, epigenetic gene regulation, plant development, and renewable energy research. The first three days of the program introduce key concepts in protein biochemistry and experimental design. The remainder of the program emphasizes full-time research supplemented with weekly sessions on ethical conduct in research, professional communication, GRE preparation, and the graduate school application process. Students present their results at a departmental symposium and a university-wide poster session. Assessment of the program will include pre- and post-surveys, poster presentation evaluations, and the BIO REU common assessment tool (SALG URSSA). The program will recruit life science and chemistry undergraduates with at least four semesters of college who have an interest in research and are members of underrepresented groups in STEM fields or attend institutions with limited research opportunities. Applications should be submitted online by early February for full consideration (see website) but will be accepted until all positions are filled. Selection of participants will be based on academic performance, demonstrated interest in research, and the potential for outstanding research careers in the life sciences.

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, improve their scientific communication skills, and have the opportunity to present the results of their work at scientific conferences.

Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://www.ag.purdue.edu/biochem/Pages/REU.aspx, or by contacting the PI (Dr. James Forney at forney@purdue.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This 10-week summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) provided scientific training for a total of 24 students over the period of three years. The research theme focused on the analysis of proteins, a class of molecules with a wide range of physical properties that often require individualized approaches for their study. During the first three days the students received a broad intellectual framework for understanding proteins and their analysis that included presentations by current graduate students and practice reading scientific publications. During the remainder of the program each student worked on an independent research project mentored by a faculty member. The projects used a wide range of techniques to investigate topics connected to protein function such as virus replication, plant metabolism, regulation of transcription and enzyme mechanisms. The research experience was supplemented with weekly professional development sessions on the ethical conduct of research, the graduate school application process and scientific communication. A written summary of the proposed project was submitted after the first three weeks, followed by poster presentations and oral presentations in the final week of the program. Practice presentations with faculty, senior graduate students and participants provided mentoring, feedback and exposed students to the diverse approaches used to tackle questions of protein function. In addition to their academic training students visited a biotechnology company and discussed career opportunities in industry.

Student surveys at the beginning and end of the program showed significant gains in ?knowledge of biochemical research methods?, ?confidence in the ability to design biochemical experiments?, ?knowledge of poster design? and the ?ability to discuss biochemical research?. A total of 11 students presented their work at national meetings. These included the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB), the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS) and Emerging Researchers National Conference in STEM. Three students were co-authors on published scientific articles in the field of biochemistry. 

The majority of participants in the program (75%) were members of underrepresented minority groups in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) and over 80% were from institutions with limited research opportunities. Thus far, 66% of the participants have enrolled in graduate or professional school, 13% are working in STEM professions and intend to pursue further education and 10% still are completing their bachelor degree. The remainder are taking ?gap year(s)? and will pursue education or work in the near future. In addition to the benefits provided to the student participants, the program provided training and mentoring opportunities for graduate student mentors as they prepare for careers in education and industry.
